We all know that May - October sees the S&P 500 up +1.5% on avg and positive 63.2% of the time since '50. But did you know it jumps to +3.8% and positive 72.5% of the time when the S&P 500 is positive YTD at any point during May? S&P 500 is up +1.7% YTD currently.

Want some good news? S&P 500 is positive YTD and it is May. You have to go back to '90 last time that happened and the full year didn't sport a total return that was positive. In fact, since '70, the full year has been green 35 out of 36 years that saw the SPX up YTD in May.

Many are looking for 20% EPS growth in '18 after a great Q1. Although we think that might be tough to hit, take note that the past 12 times S&P 500 earnings were >10% the S&P 500 Index was higher every single time - up +16.7% on avg. https://lplresearch.com/2018/03/15/what-do-strong-earnings-really-mean-for-your-investments/ …pic.twitter.com/cNWmUXgtKP

With the calendar turning to May, the economic expansion officially hit 107 months. Ranking this as the 2nd longest expansion since WWII! Longest expansions since WWII: May '91 - 120 months June '09 (current) - 107 mos Feb '61 - 106 mos Nov '82 - 92 mos Nov '01 - 73 mos

Think about this - Since '50 S&P 500 performance May through Oct (the worst 6 mos)? +1.5% on avg and higher 63.2% of time. If down best 6 mos and beneath 200-day MA? -3.7% and up 46.2%. But if up best 6 mos of yr and above 200 day MA (like '18)? +3.3% and 70.2% of the time.

The # Fed started the current cycle of rate hikes 24 months ago. Looking at the previous 9 cycles of rate hikes (1955 - 2004), it is worth noting that a recession started on avg 47 months after that first rate hike. Suggesting this business cycle could have plenty of life left.
The # SPX followed up the 4-day losing streak with the current 4-day win streak. Last time that happened was the US Election (down 9 days in a row and then a 4 day win streak).

Today will likely be the 5th rate hike of this cycle by the # Fed. Remember, the avg number of hikes until a recession is 17 (8 is the least, 34 the most). In other words, this economic cycle could have a long way to go still.

If # SPX up 4 or more months heading into March (like '17), then since 1950, March closes higher 11 of 13 times (84.6%).
Since 1950, if # SPX up in Jan and Feb (like '17) - then March closes higher 19 of 26 times (73.1%).
